inlineContent.text: Use a 'ReducerProtocol' conformance, instead.

abstract.text: A reducer describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state, given
an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.

inlineContent.text: Reducers have 3 generics:
: A type that holds the current state of the application.
: A type that holds all possible actions that cause the state of the application to
change.
: A type that holds all dependencies needed in order to produce
s,
such as API clients, analytics clients, random number generators, etc.
The thread on which effects output is important. An effect’s output is immediately
sent back into the store, and
is not thread safe. This means all effects must
receive values on the same thread,
and
if the
is being used to drive UI then all
output must be on the main thread. You can use the
method
for make
the effect output its values on the thread of your choice.
This is only an issue if using the Combine interface of
as mentioned above. If you
you are only using Swift’s concurrency tools and the
and
functions on
, then the threading is automatically handled for you.

abstract.text: Prints debug messages describing all received actions.
Transforms a reducer that works on child state, action, and environment into one that works on
parent state, action and environment.
Review unsupported reducer APIs and their replacements.
Transforms a reducer that works on non-optional state into one that works on optional state by
only running the non-optional reducer when state is non-nil.
A wrapper around a value and a hashable identifier that conforms to identifiable.
A reducer describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state, given
an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
A store represents the runtime that powers the application. It is the object that you will pass
around to views that need to interact with the application.
A version of
that transforms a reducer that works on
an element into one that works on a dictionary of element values.
Returns a reducer that applies
mutations to
before running this
reducer’s logic.
The
type encapsulates a unit of work that can be run in the outside world, and can
feed data back to the
. It is the perfect place to do side effects, such as network
requests, saving/loading from disk, creating timers, interacting with dependencies, and more.
A reducer that performs no state mutations and returns no effects.
Prints debug messages describing all received actions and state mutations.
A version of
that transforms a reducer that works on
an element into one that works on an identified array of elements.
Transforms a reducer that works on child state, action, and environment into one that works on
parent state, action and environment. It accomplishes this by providing 3 transformations to
the method:
Initializes a reducer from a simple reducer function signature.
An environment for debug-printing reducers.
Combines many reducers into a single one by running each one on state in order, and merging
all of the effects.
Instruments the reducer with
Each invocation of the reducer will be measured by an interval, and the lifecycle of its
effects will be measured with interval and event signposts.
Combines many reducers into a single one by running each one on state in order, and merging
all of the effects.
Prints debug messages describing all received actions and state mutations.
The Composable Architecture (TCA, for short) is a library for building applications in a consistent
and understandable way, with composition, testing, and ergonomics in mind. It can be used in
SwiftUI, UIKit, and more, and on any Apple platform (iOS, macOS, tvOS, and watchOS).
Combines the receiving reducer with one other reducer, running the second after the first and
merging all of the effects.
Runs the reducer.
An action that describes simple mutations to some root state at a writable key path.
A protocol that describes how to evolve the current state of an application to the next state,
given an action, and describes what
s should be executed later by the store, if any.
